 If I may add a little to what (in my opinion) is Jim's very effective contributions above:
 
 The contributors to these discussion boards are not writing essays in which it is imperative to cite sources, authorities, etc., in order to satisify a college tutor that you have understood or at least consulted the evidence relevant to your argument. If you want this kind of "back up" and scholarship, read a text book.
 
 There is no reason why mere opinion, hunches, speculations etc., should be lumbered with your "burden of proof" requirement. The only exchanges in which that would be a necessary condition in any debate is where matters of fact are disputed. What might be or what ought to be the case is obviously distinguishable from what actually is the case.
 
 Psychology is itself a morass of opinion and there is very little objective hard science in the form of quantifiable data gathered by repeatable experiments to inform it. A psychiatric opinion may be a well informed opinion - no argument here, but it's still an opinion. Have you never asked for a doctor's opinion ?
 
 As for ADD, I don't doubt (from first hand experience) that perhaps a growing number of children have difficulty in concentrating on their lessons and are hyperactive etc. I do doubt the wisdom of medicalizing the problem. Apart from exposure to junk TV and environmental factors too numerous to list but including diet possibly, there may also be a genetic predisposition among the causes - at least in some cases.
 
 A complex behavioural problem has surfaced - but whatever the "cure" may turn out to be, it seems premature or irresponsible to be prescribing drugs as a first option when its causes are so weakly understood.
